14 Gregory Hall
TJrbana, Illinois
t
May 25, 1954
Mr. Richard Hull
Radio Station WOI
Iowa State College
Ames, Iowa
Dear Dicks
Dr. Skomia has asked me to answer your letter concerning the
attrition and loss of tapes. I think you might be interested in a
paragraph of a recent letter from Jim Miless
"The Tape Network Status Sheet is a good one. I had long held
that the tape attrition was at the rate of one per calendar day. Your
figures seem to say that it is a rate slightly in excess of one and a
half per calendar day. Personally this doesn°t bother me a bit. How
you can handle as many tapes as you do with no more loss is and will con¬
tinue to be a great wonder.* •
1 Considering that we switched from the "bicycle-leg" system to
the "direct service" system a few months before Jim left this office, I
am not surprised that the attrition rate has gone up slightly.
One major cause of loss has been the return of short tapes and
bad tapes for good ones. A continual job here is the splicing together
of short tape to fill-out reels. An occasional job is the inspection of
all tapes on hand to separate the usable from the intolerably bad. I
personally have found returned tapes spliced with everything but barbed
wire. Medical tape I have found!
As long &a we allow stations to trade tapes with us, asking
only that they return tape of comparable quality—and thus far this has
seemed to be the best plan-many stations will prefer to return tapes not
quite as good as they receive; a few will actually send better tapes—
new tapes. This attitude is "only human" and natural; but it can soon
take an unhealthy bite out of the stations9 mutual supply, the NAEB Net¬
work tape stock.
Best personal regards
Sincerely,
JRHswc
